preposition.description: Having the same characteristics or qualities as; similar to.
examples: they were like brothers
she looked nothing like Audrey Hepburn
there were other suits like mine in the shop

preposition.description: Used to draw attention to the nature of an action or event.
examples: I apologize for coming over unannounced like this
why are you talking about me like that?
the cautionary vision of works like Animal Farm and 1984

conjunction.description: In the same way that; as.
examples: people who change countries like they change clothes
I felt like I'd been kicked by a camel

noun.description: Used with reference to a person or thing of the same kind as another.
examples: the quotations could be arranged to put like with like
I know him—him and his like

adjective.description: (of a person or thing) having similar qualities or characteristics to another person or thing.
examples: I responded in like manner
the grouping of children of like ability together

adverb.description: Used in speech as a meaningless filler or to signify the speaker's uncertainty about an expression just used.
examples: there was this funny smell—sort of dusty like

adverb.description: Used to convey a person's reported attitude or feelings in the form of direct speech (whether or not representing an actual quotation)
examples: so she comes into the room and she's like “Where is everybody?”
like as a ship with dreadful storm long tossed
people who don't like reading books
I like to be the center of attention
I like all Angela Carter's stories
would you like a cup of coffee?
I'd like to rent a car
I'd like you to stay
we would like for you to work for us

phrases: I've spent the entire day sorting and washing baby clothes and the like.
The boot includes hooks for shopping bags and the like and the exterior is enhanced by alloy wheels.
Eton food was all horribly unimaginative, stews and the like, and the only thing I enjoyed was fish.
Writers of fiction often use the same effect to present swift action, changes in thinking, and the like.
His siblings all went into law, medicine and the like, but he had a more artistic bent.
we could go riding if you like
You can use any vegetables - add leeks, carrots, potatoes or cauliflower if you like.
Call me a reactionary if you like, but I still think reading a work is an important first step in criticizing it.
It's cordless, so you can then pick it up and bring it right to the table, if you like.
There are a variety of committees which you can participate in if you like.
origin: Old English līcian be pleasing, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch lijken.
